      • lock

        public Unlocker lock()
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Locks this controller.

        Please note that all the fields and controllers belonging to the same controller instance share a lock. Thus, the followings is not necessary: 

          @Controller
 class MyController {
    @Autowired
   SString name;

    @Autowired
   SInteger score;

    @OnChange("name")
   void onChange(){
     try( Unlocker unlocker = score.lock() ){ // Unnecessary
       score.set( 0 );
     }
   }
 }
        When the 'onChange' method is called, the 'name' field is locked. And the 'name' field, the 'score' field and the 'MyController' controller share a lock. The 'score' field, therefore, is locked at the time the 'onChange' method is called. The only exception to this is a component annotated with SharedComponent. Shared components and fields on them do not share a lock with the others. Because shared components do not share a lock, the lock ordering is necessary to avoid concurrency issues. If locking a shared component and one of its parents at once is unavoidable, must lock a parent at first. And then lock a shared component. 
          @SharedComponent
 class MySharedComponent{}

  @Controller
 class MyController {
    @Autowired
   MySharedComponent component;

   void foo(){
     // At first lock itself, the parent of the 'this.component'
     try( Unlocker parent = lock() ) {
       // Then lock a shared component
       try( Unlocker child = component.lock() ) {
         // Do something here
       }
     }
   }
 }
        Specified by:
        lock in interface ControllerContext
        Specified by:
        lock in interface MethodContainer
        Returns:
        Unlocker instance for unlocking this lock

      • getParameter

        public java.lang.String getParameter(java.lang.String key)
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Returns the first parameter of the specified key. The parameters are taken from the query string or posted form data. 
         // HTML
  <script src="my-controller?name=John"></script>

 // Java
  @Controller
 class MyController {
    @OnCreate
   void onCreate(){
      System.out.println( getParameter("name") ); // prints "John"
   }
 }
        Specified by:
        getParameter in interface ControllerContext
        Parameters:
        key - the key of the parameter
        Returns:
        the first parameter of the specified key

         // HTML

   void onCreate(){
     System.out.println( Arrays.toString(getParameters("name")) ); // prints ["John"]
   }
 }

      • getFactoryParameters

        public com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.node.ArrayNode getFactoryParameters()
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Returns the factory parameters. The factory parameters are the parameters given to the method Factory.create(Object...). 
          @Controller
 class MyController {
    @Autowired
    ComponentFactory<MyComponent> factory;

    @OnCreate
   void onCreate(){
     factory.create(1, "John");
   }
 }

 class MyComponent extends AbstractComponent {
    @OnCreate
   void onCreate(){
     System.out.println( getFactoryParameters() ); // prints [1, "John"]
   }
 }
        Specified by:
        getFactoryParameters in interface ControllerContext
        Returns:
        the factory parameters.

      • interval

        public long interval(java.lang.String name,
                     long interval)
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Requests to call methods annotated with the OnTime of the specified name at the specified interval and returns an ID of this request. Use the returned ID and ControllerContext.cancel(long), or ControllerContext.cancel() for canceling the request. The first call is taking place after the milliseconds specified as the interval.
        Specified by:
        interval in interface ControllerContext
        Parameters:
        name - method name specified by OnTime
        interval - interval in milliseconds
        Returns:
        request ID
        See Also:
        ControllerContext.cancel(), ControllerContext.cancel(long), ControllerContext.cancelAll()

        Requests to call methods annotated with the OnTime of the specified name at the specified interval after the 'startAfter' milliseconds and returns an ID of this request. Use the returned ID and ControllerContext.cancel(long), or ControllerContext.cancel() for canceling the request. The first call is taking place after the 'startAfter' milliseconds.
        Specified by:

      • cancel

        public boolean cancel()
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Cancels the current request issued by timeout or interval methods, or the current task. Under the hood, a thread local is used to distinguish requests/tasks. 
          @Controller
 class MyController extends AbstractController {
    @OnCreate
   void onCreate(){
     interval( "update", 1000 );
   }

    @OnTime
   void update(){
     // Stops the "update" by itself
     cancel();
   }
 }
        Specified by:
        cancel in interface ControllerContext
        Returns:
        true if succeeded
        See Also:
        ControllerContext.timeout(String, long, Object...), ControllerContext.timeout(Runnable, long), ControllerContext.timeout(Callable, long), ControllerContext.interval(String, long), ControllerContext.interval(String, long, long, Object...), ControllerContext.interval(Runnable, long), ControllerContext.interval(Runnable, long, long)

      • trigger

        public void trigger(java.lang.String name,
                    java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Triggers the event of the given name at browsers. Optional arguments are passed to browsers as event data. 
         // JavaScript
 myController.on( 'hello', function( e, name ){
   console.log( name ); // prints 'John'
 });

 // Java
  @Controller
 class MyController extends AbstractController {
    @OnCreate
   void onCreate(){
     timeout( "hello", 5000 );
   }

    @OnTime
   void hello(){
     trigger( "hello", "John" );
   }
 }
        Specified by:
        trigger in interface ControllerContext
        Parameters:
        name - event name
        arguments - event data
        See Also:
        ControllerContext.triggerAndWait(String, long, Object...), ControllerContext.triggerDirect(String, Object...)

      • triggerDirect

        public void triggerDirect(java.lang.String name,
                          java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Triggers the event of the given name at browsers directly. Only difference between ControllerContext.trigger(String, Object...) and this is this method sends trigger events directly by bypassing the most of the costly synchronization processes. Thus, in general, supposed to be faster than ControllerContext.trigger(String, Object...). However, because of this, weak against network disconnections.
        Specified by:
        triggerDirect in interface ControllerContext
        Parameters:
        name - event name
        arguments - event data
        See Also:
        ControllerContext.trigger(String, Object...), ControllerContext.triggerAndWait(String, long, Object...)

      • triggerAndWait

        public TriggerResult triggerAndWait(java.lang.String name,
                                    long timeout,
                                    java.lang.Object... arguments)
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Triggers the event of the specified name at browsers and waits for responses from browsers. Optional arguments are passed to browsers as event data. When a browser send back responses within a given period of time, the callback DoneCallback set to the Promise.done(org.jdeferred.DoneCallback) is called. Otherwise, the callback FailCallback set to the Promise.fail(org.jdeferred.FailCallback) is called. 
         // JavaScript
 myController.on( 'hello', function( e, name ){
   console.log( name ); // prints 'John'
   return 'Hello, '+name;
 });

 // Java
  @Controller
 class MyController extends AbstractController {
    @OnCreate
   void onCreate(){
     timeout( "hello", 5000 );
   }

    @OnTime
   void hello(){
     trigger( "hello", 3000, "John" )
     .done(new  DoneCallback<List<JsonNode>>(){
       public void onDone( List<JsonNode> result) {
         System.out.println( result.get( 0 ).asText() ); // prints "Hello, John"
       }
     });
   }
 }
        Specified by:
        triggerAndWait in interface ControllerContext
        Parameters:
        name - event name
        timeout - timeout for this trigger in milliseconds
        arguments - event data
        Returns:
        promise instance
        See Also:
        ControllerContext.trigger(String, Object...), ControllerContext.triggerDirect(String, Object...)

      • notify

        public void notify(java.lang.String name,
                   java.lang.Object... parameters)
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Requests to call methods annotated with the OnNotice of the specified name. Notifications propagate to parents. To catch a notification triggered by a child, use a name prefixed with a child name. 
          @Component
 class MyComponent extends AbstractComponent {
   void notifyBar(){
     notify( "bar" );
   }
 }

  @Controller
 class MyController {
    @Autowired
   MyComponent foo;

    @OnNotice("foo.bar")
   void onNotice(){
     // Called when the child 'foo' sends a 'bar' notification
   }
 }
        Specified by:
        notify in interface ControllerContext
        Parameters:
        name - notification name
        parameters - notification parameters
        See Also:
        ControllerContext.notifyAsync(String, Object...)

      • notifyAsync

        public void notifyAsync(java.lang.String name,
                        java.lang.Object... parameters)
        Description copied from interface: ControllerContext
        Requests to call methods annotated with the OnNotice of the specified name asynchronously. Notifications propagate to parents. To catch a notification triggered by a child, use a name prefixed with a child name. 
          @Component
 class MyComponent extends AbstractComponent {
   void notifyBar(){
     notifyAsync( "bar" );
   }
 }

  @Controller
 class MyController {
    @Autowired
   MyComponent foo;

    @OnNotice("foo.bar")
   void onNotice(){
     // Called when the child 'foo' sends a 'bar' notification
   }
 }
        Specified by:
        notifyAsync in interface ControllerContext
        Parameters:
        name - notification name
        parameters - notification parameters
        See Also:
        ControllerContext.notify(String, Object...)
